chapter.title: Advanced Usage
chapter.para: This chapter covers several advanced usage topics.

section.title: Test Skipping
section.para: There are times where the test code you have written is just not applicable to the system you are running on. This section describes how to skip these tests but maintain the total test count.

Probably the easiest example would be shell code that is meant to run under the bash shell, but the unit test is running under the Bourne shell. There are things that just won't work. The following test code demonstrates two sample functions, one that will be run under any shell, and the another that will run only under the bash shell.

example.title: math.inc -- math include

section.para: And here is a corresponding unit test that correctly skips the add_bash() function when the unit test is not running under the bash shell.

example.title: math_test -- math unit test

section.para: Running the above test under the bash shell will result in the following output.
section.screen:
# # Performing tests # testAdding
# # Test report # tests passed: 2 100% tests failed: 0 0% tests skipped: 0 0% tests total: 2 100%
section.para: But, running the test under any other shell will result in the following output.
section.screen:
# # Performing tests # testAdding
# # Test report # tests passed: 1 50% tests failed: 0 0% tests skipped: 1 50% tests total: 2 100%
section.para: As you can see, the total number of tests has not changed, but the report indicates that some tests were skipped.

Skipping can be controlled with the following functions: startSkipping(), stopSkipping(), and isSkipping. Once skipping is enabled, it will remain enabled until the end of the current test function call, after which skipping is disabled.
